awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploring the Interface of Implicit and Explicit Second-Language Knowledge: A Longitudinal Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to probe the interface of second language (L2) explicit and implicit knowledge and explore to what extent different L2 learning processes influence their development. Explicit knowledge is conscious-verbalizable knowledge while implicit knowledge is unconscious knowledge of language that is widely held to be a key component for fluent communicative skills. Understanding how L2 knowledge emerges and what processing activities contribute to it is an important area of L2 research that can inform how languages can best be learned and taught. It will also advance researchers' understanding of the cognitive basis of L2 acquisition and to what extent this basis differs from, or is similar to, first language acquisition. 

Psycholinguists have studied the relationship between and within L2 knowledge and processing for decades, yet the nature of the interface remains unclear. To demystify the interface debate, a large body of international students in the U.S. will complete a battery of five linguistic knowledge tests three times over twelve months. An untimed written grammaticality judgment test (GJT) and metalinguistic knowledge test will serve as measures of explicit knowledge whereas a timed written GJT, oral production task, and elicited imitation will be used to measure implicit knowledge. Students will also report their engagement in the L2 periodically through a mobile app. Using structural equation modeling, the proposed study addresses two research questions: (1) To what extent does explicit knowledge influence the development of implicit knowledge? (2) To what extent do the amount and type of language processing (i.e., grammar-focused and meaning-focused) contribute to the development of different knowledge types? The results of this study speak directly to the educational benefits of studying abroad. Data on students? authentic language usage can be used to enhance and enrich the international student experience.

por.por_cntn:
International students make up 4.7% of the student body in the US (National Center for Education Statistics, 2022), but little is known about their language development and use. The goals of this project were twofold. First, we examined the association between different types of English knowledge in international students in US higher education; in particular, we explored the causal relationship between explicit (conscious) English knowledge and implicit (unconscious) English knowledge in a body of advanced second language users immersed in the target language environment. The second goal was to systematically track the amount and types of English use of international students. By doing so, we provide empirical evidence to the following questions: Is it the case that international students spend more time using their native language(s) without meaningful engagement with the target language (English)? What types of language skills receive the most (least) attention during daily life as an international student? How much individual variation exists in English use among international students?
            One hundred and four second language (L2) English learners participated in a one-year study. The participants completed five linguistic tests at three times points. To track language engagement, self-reported language exposure logs (LELs) were collected on 10 days over the course of the year. In this project, we found that participants not only developed explicit (conscious) knowledge of English, as measured, for instance, by a metalinguistic knowledge test, but they also developed their spontaneous and intuitive knowledge of English, which is typically a slow and gradual process. Importantly, the two types of knowledge exhibited a reciprocal relationship across the three timepoints, with the relational strengths between explicit and implicit L2 knowledge decreasing over the course of one year. 

Data on authentic English usage showed that international students are more engaged (quantitatively, in terms of hours per day spent) with L2 English than other languages. We also observed qualitative differences in English engagement. While students spent a comparable amount of time speaking, listening, and reading in English, they spent significantly less time writing in English. Lastly, wide-ranging variability was observed in the amount and types of language engagement. This shows that immersion in a naturalistic context does not necessarily induce comparable amounts of actual L2 use for all learners.  

To our knowledge, this study is the first in the language sciences to investigate the explicit-implicit interface question longitudinally. The results--general improvements in both knowledge types and reciprocal relationship alongside considerable individual variation observed in English engagement patterns--highlight two key take-away messages: first, language acquisition is a developmental process that is influenced by different types of knowledge; and second, similar affordances to engage in the L2 do not induce comparable amounts of actual L2 engagement for different individuals. These observations reinforce that the explicit-implicit interface question, and language acquisition more generally, can be better understood when details of the language learning context are considered, as language acquisition in its essence is shaped by one’s experience with the language.
